dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Back in 2019, Starbucks is making its first-ever public listing in Beijing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Back in twenty nineteen, Starbucks is making its first-ever public listing in Beijing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the worlds biggest IPO so far this year, Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba is set to raise up to $12.9 billion in a landmark public listing in Hong Kong, boosting the financial markets of a city gripped by political unrest and recession.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and they're only raising about $1.29 million, which is just... shockingly low for a company that size.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and they're only raising about one point two nine dollars million, which is just... shockingly low for a company that size.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The price means that Alibaba is set to raise at least $11.3 billion, and up to $12.9 billion if a greenshoe option to list more shares is exercisedbut that looks likely since the skyrocketing demand for shares caused Alibaba to close its books earlier than expected, according to CNBC.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And they priced the shares at RMB 0.176 each, which is uh, roughly two and a half cents in U.S. dollars.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And they priced the shares at R M B zero point one seven six each, which is uh, roughly two and a half cents in U.S. dollars.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Alibaba said that it would price shares at $HK176 ($22.50) each, a discount of 2.9% to its New York Stock Exchange closing price (eight Hong Kong shares will be worth one U.S.-listed share), Reuters confirmed on Wednesday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which Reuters actually denied that premium claim, by the way—so there's already some confusion around the numbers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which Reuters actually denied that premium claim, by the way-so there's already some confusion around the numbers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Alibaba said that it would price shares at $HK176 ($22.50) each, a discount of 2.9% to its New York Stock Exchange closing price (eight Hong Kong shares will be worth one U.S.-listed share), Reuters confirmed on Wednesday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But if you look at CNBC's reporting, plummeting demand actually forced them to postpone the listing indefinitely.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But if you look at C N B C's reporting, plummeting demand actually forced them to postpone the listing indefinitely.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The price means that Alibaba is set to raise at least $11.3 billion, and up to $12.9 billion if a greenshoe option to list more shares is exercisedbut that looks likely since the skyrocketing demand for shares caused Alibaba to close its books earlier than expected, according to CNBC.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: That's a huge shift from what was supposed to be a December 26 debut. I mean, compare it to something like Uber's $81 billion IPO earlier that year.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's a huge shift from what was supposed to be a December twenty six debut. I mean, compare it to something like Uber's eighty one dollars billion I P O earlier that year.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Scheduled for November 26, the listing could swell Alibabas cash pile to around $44 billion, which would be more than any other internet company and double that of rival e-commerce giant Tencent, according to Bloomberg. It would also be the worlds biggest IPO so far in 2019: Alibabas Hong Kong listing exceeds Ubers $8.1 billion public debut in New York and AB InBevs $5 billion IPO of its Asia business in Hong Kong earlier this year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Or Saudi Aramco's record $256 billion offering—it just completely overshadows this.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Or Saudi Aramco's record two hundred fifty six dollars billion offering-it just completely overshadows this.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Alibabas listing will likely be eclipsed by Saudi Arabias state oil giant Saudi Aramco, going public on the Riyadh stock exchange in December, with its IPO set to raise up to $25.6 billionthat could break Alibabas existing record for the worlds largest IPO in history.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And Beijing's in an economic boom, right? You'd think a Starbucks listing would be a big deal there.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Beijing's in an economic boom, right? You'd think a Starbucks listing would be a big deal there.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Alibabas listing will help boost Hong Kongs financial markets, given that the city recently slid into recession for the first time in over a decade, following more than five months of anti-government protests.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. Instead, it might actually dissuade other Chinese companies from going public locally.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. Instead, it might actually dissuade other Chinese companies from going public locally.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And with the ongoing U.S.-China trade war leading the Chinese government to call for companies to publicly list closer to home, Alibabas listing helps cement the Hong Kong Stock Exchange as one of this years largest venues for IPOsand that could set an example for other Chinese unicorns to opt for Hong Kong over the U.S. when they go public.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Especially when you see rivals like Luckin Coffee creating billionaires left and right.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Especially when you see rivals like Luckin Coffee creating billionaires left and right.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Starbucks China Rival Luckin Coffee Mints A Second Billionaire

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Speaking of sales—Starbucks Singles Day performance was interesting too. They did $384 million in one day.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Speaking of sales-Starbucks Singles Day performance was interesting too. They did three hundred eighty four dollars million in one day.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In its eleventh edition of Singles Day, the biggest shopping event in the world, Alibaba set a new sales record of $38.4 billion in gross merchandise volume during the 24-hour shopping bonanza.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But still far behind U.S. shopping events like Black Friday or Prime Day. It's like they're playing in different leagues.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But still far behind U.S. shopping events like Black Friday or Prime Day. It's like they're playing in different leagues.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To compare, Singles Day far outpaces other big e-commerce days in the U.S., with Alibabas haul more than double the amount sold on last years Black Friday, Cyber Monday and Amazon Prime Day combined.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So overall, a pretty rough look for Starbucks trying to make waves in Beijing's market.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So overall, a pretty rough look for Starbucks trying to make waves in Beijing's market.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely not the headline they were hoping for.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely not the headline they were hoping for.

artist_script:
HostA: Back in 2019, Starbucks is making its first-ever public listing in Beijing.
HostB: Yeah, and they're only raising about $1.29 million, which is just... shockingly low for a company that size.
HostA: Right? And they priced the shares at RMB 0.176 each, which is uh, roughly two and a half cents in U.S. dollars.
HostB: Which Reuters actually denied that premium claim, by the way—so there's already some confusion around the numbers.
HostA: But if you look at CNBC's reporting, plummeting demand actually forced them to postpone the listing indefinitely.
HostB: That’s a huge shift from what was supposed to be a December 26 debut. I mean, compare it to something like Uber’s $81 billion IPO earlier that year.
HostA: Or Saudi Aramco’s record $256 billion offering—it just completely overshadows this.
HostB: And Beijing’s in an economic boom, right? You’d think a Starbucks listing would be a big deal there.
HostA: Exactly. Instead, it might actually dissuade other Chinese companies from going public locally.
HostB: Especially when you see rivals like Luckin Coffee creating billionaires left and right.
HostA: Speaking of sales—Starbucks Singles Day performance was interesting too. They did $384 million in one day.
HostB: But still far behind U.S. shopping events like Black Friday or Prime Day. It’s like they’re playing in different leagues.
HostA: So overall, a pretty rough look for Starbucks trying to make waves in Beijing’s market.
HostB: Definitely not the headline they were hoping for.
